title: Hallucination Detection in LLMs Using Spectral Features of Attention Maps
author: Jakub Binkowski (Wroclaw University of Science and Technology), Denis Janiak (Wroclaw University of Science and Technology), Albert Sawczyn (Wroclaw University of Science and Technology), Bogdan Gabrys (University of Technology Sydney), Tomasz Kajdanowicz (Wroclaw University of Science and Technology), ...
relevance_why: The use of spectral features from attention maps could inform methods for audio and speech modeling, particularly in improving audio representations and enhancing model robustness against erroneous outputs.
background: This paper addresses hallucinations in Large Language Models (LLMs), specifically focusing on detecting nonsensical or incorrect outputs by analyzing attention map properties.
contribution: This paper introduces the LapEigvals method to solve hallucination detection in LLMs, achieving state-of-the-art performance through the use of top-k eigenvalues from Laplacian matrices derived from attention maps.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods for hallucination detection rely on simpler metrics or models, often yielding limited accuracy.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves detection capabilities by leveraging the spectral information contained in the Laplacian matrix, which provides richer insights into model behavior.

key_innovation: The unique approach of using graph theory concepts to analyze attention maps enables better prediction of hallucination instances through eigenvalue characteristics.
real_world_impact: This method has potential applications in safety-critical systems where the reliability of LLM outputs is paramount, improving user trust and the applicability of LLMs in sensitive areas.
limitations: The authors note that their supervised method requires labeled data for training the hallucination probe, which may introduce noise.

new_terms.Laplacian matrix: **Laplacian matrix** is used in graph theory to represent the graph structure, specifically highlighting the relationship between nodes (in this case, tokens in a language model) and their connectivity.
new_terms.spectral features: **Spectral features** refer to characteristics derived from the eigenvalues of matrices, which provide insights into graph properties and system behaviors.

open_sourcing: The implementation is available in a public repository: https://github.com/graphml-lab-pwr/lapeig
